abstract_summ: The study also emphasizes the importance of pathogen genomics through phylogenetic analysis to discover viral genetic diversity and understand the viral transmission dynamics with eventual grasp on viral virulence and disease pathogenesis.We performed whole-genome sequencing for 64 genomes making a total of 361 genomes from India, followed by phylogenetic clustering, substitution analysis, and dating of the different phylogenetic clusters of viral genomes.We describe a distinct phylogenetic cluster (Clade I / A3i) of SARS-CoV-2 genomes from India, which encompasses 41% of all genomes sequenced and deposited in the public domain from multiple states in India.The association of the virus spread from the market is supported by the close relation of genome sequences of environmental surface samples with virus samples from earliest patients by phylogenetic analysis.The comparison of genetic variants of fourty North African strains revealed that two non-synonymous mutations D614G (in spike) and Q57H (in ORF3a) were common in four countries (Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria and Egypt), with a prevalence of 92.5% (n = 37) and 42.5% (n = 17), respectively, of the total genomes.
title_summ: Variant analysis of SARS-CoV-2 strains in Middle Eastern countriesGenetic diversity among SARS-CoV2 strains in South America may impact performance of Molecular detectionA distinct phylogenetic cluster of Indian SARS-CoV-2 isolatesGenomics of Indian SARS-CoV-2: Implications in genetic diversity, possible origin and spread of virusGenetic analysis of SARS-CoV-2 strains collected from North Africa: viral origins and mutational spectrumEvidence for mutations in SARS‐CoV‐2 Italian isolates potentially affecting virus transmissionGenetic variants and source of introduction of SARS‐CoV‐2 in South AmericaGenome analysis of SARS-CoV-2 isolates occurring in India: Present scenario.
